Authors: Miyamoto T., Tsujimoto N., Kumagai S.
Title: A cooperative algorithm for autonomous distributed vehicle systems with finite buffer capacity
Source title: IEICE Transactions on Fundamentals of Electronics, Communications and Computer Sciences
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Osaka University, Suita-shi, 565-0871, Japan; Department of Electrical, Electronic and Information Engineering, Osaka University, Japan; IEEE, Japan; SICE, Japan; ISCIE, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyamoto, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Osaka University, Suita-shi, 565-0871, Japan, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Information Engineering, Osaka University, Japan, IEEE, Japan, SICE, Japan, ISCIE, Japan; Tsujimoto, N., Department of Electrical Engineering, Osaka University, Suita-shi, 565-0871, Japan; Kumagai, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Osaka University, Suita-shi, 565-0871, Japan, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Information Engineering, Osaka University, Japan
Abstract: Recently, there are so many researches on Autonomous Distributed Manufacturing Systems (ADMSs), where cooperation among agents is used to solve problems, such as the scheduling problem and the vehicle routing problem. We target ADMSs where an ADMS consists of two sub-systems: a Production System (PS) and an Autonomous Transportation System (ATS). This paper discusses an on-line Tasks Assignment and Routing Problem (TARP) for ATSs under conditions of given production schedule and finite buffer capacity. The TARP results in a constrained version of the Pickup and Delivery Problem with Time Windows (PDPTW), and this paper gives a mathematical formulation of the problem. This paper, also, proposes a cooperative algorithm to obtain suboptimal solutions in which no deadlocks and buffer overflows occur. By computational experiments, we will examine the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. Computational experiments show that the proposed algorithm is able to obtain efficient and deadlock-free routes even though the buffer p capacity is less. Copyright © 2005 The Institute of Electronics, Information and Communication Engineers.

Authors: Bandara J.M.S.J., Wong S.C.
Title: Special issue: Some recent advances in transportation modeling
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka; Department of Civil Engineering, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Bandara, J.M.S.J., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka; Wong, S.C., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: Some of the latest modeling advances in the planning, management, and operation of transportation systems are described. The emerging modeling issues for the planning of transportation systems include land use and transportation interaction, network reliability, network design problems, and sustainable transportation problems. The latest modeling issues to surface in the management of transportation systems include road pricing, traffic control, and the provision of information. Latest issues in the operation of transportation systems include vehicle dispatch problems, transit scheduling problems, the development of traffic flow models, and the education and training of road users.
Index Keywords: Industrial management; Land use; Mathematical models; Planning; Reliability; Scheduling; Sustainable development; Traffic control; Network design; Network reliability; Road pricing; Sustainable transportation; Motor transportation

Authors: Ganesh K., Narendran T.T.
Title: CLOSE: a heuristic to solve a precedence-constrained travelling salesman problem with delivery and pickup
Source title: International Journal of Services and Operations Management
Affiliations: Department of Management Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Chennai 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Ganesh, K., Department of Management Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Chennai 600036, India; Narendran, T.T., Department of Management Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Chennai 600036, India
Abstract: Logistics Management sometimes involves pickup as well as delivery along the route. Courier service is a typical example. The imposition of precedence constraints among the places to be visited constitutes a variant of the classical Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP). This well-known np-hard problem is often solved by heuristics. The Precedence-Constrained TSP that incorporates Delivery and Pickup (PCTDP) is a much harder problem to solve. This paper addresses the PCTDP and presents a three-stage heuristic using clustering and shrink-wrap algorithm for finding an initial path as well as genetic algorithms for the final search to obtain the best solution. The proposed heuristic is tested over a range of trial datasets and is found to give encouraging results. With its ability to provide solutions of good quality at low computing times, the proposed heuristic has ample scope for application as an automated scheduler when implemented at the site of a logistics-planning cell. © 2005 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: delivery and pickup; logistics; precedence constraint; travelling salesman problem

Abstract: The naïve tabu search (NTS) has been enhanced with two adaptive mechanisms namely back-tracking and adaptive search radius. The proposed search is called adaptive tabu search (ATS). The paper provides convergence and performance analyses of the ATS. © Springer-Verlag 2004.

Authors: Song J., DePuy G.W., Evans G.W.
Title: A meta-heuristic for the multi-vehicle dial-a-ride problem with time windows
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States
Authors with affiliations: Song, J., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States; DePuy, G.W., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States; Evans, G.W., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States
Abstract: The multi-vehicle Dial-A-Ride Problem with Time Windows (DARPTW) is one of the well-known combinatorial optimization problems. It has become important recently because of the social, economic and environmental issues associated with on-demand public transportation. However, due to the complexity of this problem, it is difficult to get good solutions for large-scale dial-a-ride transit problems in a reasonable time. A new DARPTW meta-heuristic is proposed here, based on the main characteristics of two established heuristics: Meta-RaPS and Scatter Search.
Author Keywords: DARPTW; Memory-based heuristic; Meta-RaPS; Scatter Search; Sequential insertion
Index Keywords: Metadata; Optimization; Problem solving; Transportation; Memory-based heuristic; Meta-RaPS; Scatter search; Sequential insertion; Heuristic methods

Authors: Shinoda K., Noda I., Ohta M., Kumada Y., Nakashima H.
Title: Is dial-a-ride bus reasonable in large scale towns? Evaluation of usability of dial-a-ride systems by simulation
Source title: Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence (Subseries of Lecture Notes in Computer Science)
Affiliations: Cyber Assist Research Center, AIST, 135-0064 Aomi, Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 923-1292 asahidai, Tatunokuti Nomi Ishikawa, Japan; PRESTO, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shinoda, K., Cyber Assist Research Center, AIST, 135-0064 Aomi, Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 923-1292 asahidai, Tatunokuti Nomi Ishikawa, Japan; Noda, I., Cyber Assist Research Center, AIST, 135-0064 Aomi, Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 923-1292 asahidai, Tatunokuti Nomi Ishikawa, Japan, PRESTO, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan; Ohta, M., Cyber Assist Research Center, AIST, 135-0064 Aomi, Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan; Kumada, Y., Cyber Assist Research Center, AIST, 135-0064 Aomi, Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 923-1292 asahidai, Tatunokuti Nomi Ishikawa, Japan; Nakashima, H., Cyber Assist Research Center, AIST, 135-0064 Aomi, Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 923-1292 asahidai, Tatunokuti Nomi Ishikawa, Japan
Abstract: Dial-a-ride systems are attracting attention as a new style of transportation systems for urban areas. While it has been reported that such systems improve the usability of bus systems when applied in a small town or area, it is not obvious how and under what conditions the systems are effective in comparison to traditional fixed-route bus systems. We conducted two computer simulations of dial-a-ride and fixed-route systems in order to compare the usability and profitability of both systems. Simulation results indicated that: (1) The usability of the dial-a-ride system with a fixed number of buses drops very quickly when the number of requests(demands) increases. (2) When we increase the number of buses proportionally to the number of demand, the usability of the dial-a-ride system is improved more significantly than that of the fixed-route system. (3) When frequency of demands is sufficiently, the dial-a-ride system is a reasonable solution from the both usability and profitability perspectives. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2004.

Authors: Attanasio A., Cordeau J.-F., Ghiani G., Laporte G.
Title: Parallel Tabu search heuristics for the dynamic multi-vehicle dial-a-ride problem
Affiliations: Ctro. Eccellenza Calcolo Alte P., Univ. degli Studi della Calabria, 87030 Rende (CS), Italy; Canada Res. Chair in Distr. Mgmt., HEC Montreal 3000 Chemin Cote-S.-C., Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada; Dipto. di Ing. dell'Innovazione, Univ. degli Studi di Lecce, 73100 Lecce, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Attanasio, A., Ctro. Eccellenza Calcolo Alte P., Univ. degli Studi della Calabria, 87030 Rende (CS), Italy; Cordeau, J.-F., Canada Res. Chair in Distr. Mgmt., HEC Montreal 3000 Chemin Cote-S.-C., Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada; Ghiani, G., Dipto. di Ing. dell'Innovazione, Univ. degli Studi di Lecce, 73100 Lecce, Italy; Laporte, G., Canada Res. Chair in Distr. Mgmt., HEC Montreal 3000 Chemin Cote-S.-C., Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Abstract: In the Dial-a-Ride problem (DARP) users specify transportation requests between origins and destinations to be served by vehicles. In the dynamic DARP, requests are received throughout the day and the primary objective is to accept as many requests as possible while satisfying operational constraints. This article describes and compares a number of parallel implementations of a Tabu search heuristic previously developed for the static DARP, i.e., the variant of the problem where all requests are known in advance. Computational results show that the proposed algorithms are able to satisfy a high percentage of user requests. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Mitrović-Minić S., Laporte G.
Title: Waiting strategies for the dynamic pickup and delivery problem with time windows
Affiliations: School of Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC V5A 1S6, Canada; Canada Res. Chair in Distr. Mgmt., Ecole des Hautes Etud. Commerciales, Montreal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mitrović-Minić, S., School of Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC V5A 1S6, Canada; Laporte, G., Canada Res. Chair in Distr. Mgmt., Ecole des Hautes Etud. Commerciales, Montreal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Abstract: The dynamic pickup and delivery problem with time windows arises in courier companies making same-day pickup and delivery of letters and small parcels. In this problem solution quality is affected by the way waiting time is distributed along vehicle routes. This article defines and compares four waiting strategies. An extensive empirical study is carried out on instances generated using real-life data. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Mitrović-Minić S., Krishnamurti R., Laporte G.
Title: Double-horizon based heuristics for the dynamic pickup and delivery problem with time windows
Affiliations: School of Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC V5A 1S6, Canada; Canada Research Chair in Distr Mgmt, HEC Montréal, Montreal H3T 2A7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mitrović-Minić, S., School of Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC V5A 1S6, Canada; Krishnamurti, R., School of Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC V5A 1S6, Canada; Laporte, G., Canada Research Chair in Distr Mgmt, HEC Montréal, Montreal H3T 2A7, Canada
Abstract: The dynamic Pickup and Delivery Problem with Time Windows (PDPTW) is faced by courier companies serving same-day pickup and delivery requests for the transport of letters and small parcels. This article focuses on the dynamic PDPTW for which future requests are not stochastically modelled or predicted. The standard solution methodology for the dynamic PDPTW is the use of a rolling time horizon as proposed by Psaraftis. When assigning a new request to a vehicle it may be preferable to consider the impact of a decision both on a short-term and on a long-term horizon. In particular, better managing slack time in the distant future may help reduce routing cost. This paper describes double-horizon based heuristics for the dynamic PDPTW. Computational results show the advantage of using a double-horizon in conjunction with insertion and improvement heuristics. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Dynamic pickup and delivery problem with time windows; On-line heuristic; Rolling time horizon; Short-term and long-term time horizons
Index Keywords: Costs; Heuristic methods; Industrial management; Mathematical models; Postal services; Stochastic control systems; Parcels; Rolling time horizone; Routing cost; Stochastic modeling; Transportation; heuristics
